profileText: A Senator from Idaho; born on a farm near Jonesboro, Jackson Parish, La., March 31, 1884; attended the common schools; graduated from Louisiana Polytechnic Institute, Ruston, La., in 1906 and from the law department of the University of Chicago, Chicago, Ill., 1909; admitted to the bar in 1909 and commenced practice in Boise, Idaho; deputy collector of internal revenue 1916; city attorney of Boise 1916-1917; assistant attorney general of Idaho 1918-1919; member of the board of education of Boise 1924-1929; mayor of Boise 1929-1933, when he resigned, having been elected to Congress; elected as a Democrat to the United States Senate and served from March 4, 1933, to January 3, 1939; unsuccessful candidate for renomination in 1938; appointed a director of the Tennessee Valley Authority by President Franklin D. Roosevelt 1939-1951; associated with law firm in Knoxville, Tenn.; member of board of directors, Federal Savings & Loan Association, Knoxville, Tenn.; moved to Alexandria, Va., in 1963, where he resided until his death there on January 23, 1966; interment in Lynnhurst Cemetery, Knoxville, Tenn.

creativeWork.freeFormCitationText: Sims, Robert C. "James P. Pope, Senator from Idaho.'' Idaho Yesterdays 15 (Fall 1971): 9-15.

researchRecord.name: Copies of correspondence (1939-1950) with Pope in David E. Lilienthal additional papers collection, 1939-1985.

1910-1931. 10 feet. Personal and office correspondence, case files, miscellaneous office bills and receipts, personal clippings, and personal files relating to his law practice, and to Idaho and national affairs of the Democratic party during the 1920s. Finding aid. Also 3 linear feet of scrapbooks (1929-1951) maintained while mayor of Boise, U.S. senator, and director of Tennessee Valley Authority.
Correspondence in Robert Coulter papers, 1931-1944; George Curtis papers, 1905-1959; Allan B. Eaton papers, 1934-1945; and campaign records in Mrs. Vernon H. Tregaskis papers, 1928-1948.
Ca. 1930-1950. 10 scrapbooks, speeches, clippings, photographs, and reports covering political career. Finding aid.
1 letter in Senate Committee on Foreign Relations correspondence with Theodore Dreiser, 1934.
1939-1951. 11 feet. Correspondence, articles, speeches, and other papers relating his work as director of the Tennessee Valley Authority. Finding aid.
